title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DETROIT (AP) — The final score, a 95-66 demolition of the Sacramento Kings, will be a footnote. The box score will tell of a dominant Detroit Pistons victory, but it will scream the name of one man: Joe Dumars.

In an era defined by defensive grit, Dumars authored an offensive masterpiece for the ages. On this night in 1997, The Palace of Auburn Hills bore witness to a historic, career-defining explosion. Dumars, the consummate professional and usually a model of efficient scoring, transformed into an unstoppable force, pouring in a career-high 42 points.

From the opening tip, it was clear something special was brewing. Dumars attacked with a ruthless precision, a symphony of mid-range jumpers and relentless drives to the basket. The Kings, helpless to find an answer, could only watch as the veteran guard methodically dismantled their defense. Each basket was a statement, each swish of the net a crescendo in a one-man show of offensive brilliance.

His 42 points were not just a personal best; they were a testament to his enduring greatness and a stark reminder of the explosive potential that lay within his fundamentally sound game. He single-handedly outscored the entire Kings team through three quarters, a stat line so absurd it defies belief.

While the Pistons' defense deserves its share of credit for holding Sacramento to a paltry 66 points, this night belonged solely to Joe Dumars. It was a performance that transcended a simple regular-season win, a scoring barrage that etched his name deeper into the franchise's lore and left an indelible mark on all who witnessed it. In a 95-point team effort, 42 of them were a legendary solo.
